reviews.body:
Generally looks pretty good. Can you add a couple protections:

- If the device has no LAG defined.
- If the device's first LAG has no member.

You can return the test is skipped.

comments.body: Fixes #1372

> @tahmed-dev please check the PR as it fixes an issue observed following some changes provided by you.
> To me the fix seems to be correct but the problem is that i am not sure if this was missed or by intention and the fix need to be different.
> NOTE: who ever try to run non t0 topo is currently blocked as of that.

Thanks @liat-grozovik Every t0 variant device is a ToR device. Current practice is to identify the device type by checking the dut_type from the topology file. this could be seen in:

https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/vars/topo_t0.yml#L77 and 
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/vars/topo_t1.yml#L135

Which topo was used to produce this issue? Is it in public repo?

Hi @tahmed-dev, 
I saw the error in t1 and t1-lag. I suspect it can be reproduced in any non-t0 topo.

> This previous format works too, the issue was with the extra double quotation
> 
> ```
> when: ('host_interfaces' in vm_topo_config) and ('tor' in vm_topo_config['dut_type'] | lower)
> ```
> 
> Please fix this one to get going and I will take care of the rest.

Understood.
I will do it in this way.

reviews.body:
Every t0 variant is a ToR device and so the check for 'tor' in vm_topo_config['dut_type'] suffices.

Which topo file was used to generate this error? is it missing dut_type field?

reviews.body: @tahmed-dev: Can you please add a description to the PR, explaining what you did and why you did it? We provide the description template as a guide.
As comments, plus please make PR title clearer.

comments.body: @daall Could you please take a look to the PR.
@baiwei0427  Why do we need this change? Also ptf_unknown

> @baiwei0427 Why do we need this change? Also ptf_unknown

@pavel-shirshov When we want to use AnsibleHost class to control a PTF instance, we must know its host name to get access information from the inventory file (e.g., https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/veos.vtb). However, in current testbed CSV files, you can only know the IP address of PTF.
@sujinmkang would you please help to review?

@keboliu & @Junchao-Mellanox  can we have the hld PR reviewed with reviewers first? https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/pull/547
I will also review the hld too.

latestReviews.body: Looks OK to me. @sujinmkang to review as well.

reviews.body: See comments. I'm mostly concerned about combined L2/L3 counters, but the redundancy could make this hard to maintain in the future. Let me know if you have any questions. :)
LGTM, please fix the merge conflicts and see Xin's comments. :)

comments.body:
Hi @chitra-raghavan
Have you ever try to run pytest cases on ansible-2.8.7?

@chitra-raghavan @lguohan, I am not clear why this test case is trying to download things directly from the internet to do the validation. Is there any special purpose? Why not download the file from the PTF container?

@gord1306  ,  

> Hi @chitra-raghavan
> Have you ever try to run pytest cases on ansible-2.8.7?

I haven't validated this in 2.8.7 ansible

> @chitra-raghavan @lguohan, I am not clear why this test case is trying to download things directly from the internet to do the validation. Is there any special purpose? Why not download the file from the PTF container?

As of now ptf docker  doesn't have http/https configuration. Hence used available  Sonic links  for wget/curl tests
